content: As you already used some features as lightning, you now want to create a series of images with a strong composition.
To do this, we have to start by understanding some basic principles.
The Rule of Thirds is a fundamental composition principle that involves dividing the image into a 3x3 grid.
Key elements are placed along the grid lines or at their intersections to create a balanced and engaging composition.

question: Why is the Rule of Thirds important in composition?

options.text: It places all elements in the center of the image
It helps create balance and visual interest

explanation: Using a grid helps in placing elements in a way that creates balance and visual interest.

content: Let's practice using the Rule of Thirds to create a balanced composition.

title: Practicing the Rule of Thirds
instruction: Fill in the gap to create an image using the Rule of Thirds.

content: Leading lines are used to guide the viewer's eye through the image and towards the focal point.
These lines can be roads, rivers, fences, or any other elements that draw attention to the main subject.

question: How do leading lines enhance composition?

options.text: They make the image look cluttered
They guide the viewer's eye through the image

explanation: Leading lines are used to direct attention and create a sense of movement within the image.

content: Let's practice using leading lines to direct the viewer's gaze.

title: Using Leading Lines
instruction: Fill in the gap to create an image using leading lines to guide the viewer's gaze.

content: Balance and symmetry involve arranging elements in the image so that they are evenly distributed, creating a sense of stability and harmony.
Symmetrical compositions often evoke a sense of order and calm.

title: Balance and Symmetry
instruction: Fill in the gap to create an image using balance and symmetry.

content:
Compositional techniques can be used to direct the viewer's gaze and create focal points.

By strategically placing elements and using visual cues, you can guide the viewer's attention to the most important parts of the image.

title: Directing the Viewer's Gaze
instruction: Fill in the gap to create an image.

content:
Different angles can add interest and variety to your compositions. Here are some common angles to experiment with:
- Macro: Extreme close-up of small details.
- Close-up: Focused view of the subject.
- Wide Angle: Expansive view of the scene.

-Diagonal Angle: Adds dynamic movement.
- Aerial: View from above.
- High Angle: Looking down on the subject.
- Low Angle: Looking up at the subject.
- Oblique Angle: Tilted view for a dramatic effect.

title: Using Different Angles
instruction: Fill in the gap to create an image from a specific angle.

content: You've now learned how to use compositional techniques to enhance your AI art. Keep practicing and refining your prompts to create even more harmonious and visually appealing images.
In the next lesson, we'll explore the blend mode. Stay creative and keep experimenting!
